Items.Title: Roll Call
Invocation
Items.AgendaNote:
INVOCATION - Delivered by: Venerable You Lin, Director, Fo Guang Shan New York Temple/International Buddhist Society located at 154-37 Barclay Ave., Flushing, NY 11355.

Motion to spread the Invocation in full upon the record by Council Member Keith Ung.
Items.MinutesNote:
The Invocation was delivered by: Venerable You Lin, Director, Fo Guang Shan New York Temple/International Buddhist Society located at 154-37 Barclay Ave., Flushing, N.Y. 11355.

Council Member Ung moved to spread the Invocation in full upon the Record.

Items.Title: Adoption of Minutes

Items.Title: Petitions and Communications
Land Use Call-Ups

By Council Member Bottcher:
Pursuant to Sections 11.20b and 11.20c of the Council Rules and Section 197-d(b)(3) of the New York City Charter, the Council hereby resolves that the actions of the City Planning Commission on Uniform Land Use Review Procedure Application Numbers C 200012 ZSM and C 200013 ZSM (213-227 West 28th Street Parking Special Permits) shall be subject to Council review.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Zoning, 213-227 West 28th Street Parking Special Permits, Manhattan (C 200012 ZSM and C 200013 ZSM)

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to promoting housing stability for older adults by making available full legal representation in eviction or termination of tenancy proceedings in housing court for any person who is 60 years of age or older and establishing a housing support program for persons 60 years of age or older who are at risk of eviction or foreclosure

Items.MatterName: Aging In Place Package - Promoting housing stability for seniors by entitling any person who is 60 years of age or older to full legal representation in eviction or termination of tenancy proceedings in housing court.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on Congress to pass, and the President to sign, a bill in support of self-determination for Puerto Rico.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Support of self-determination for Puerto Rico.

Introduction & Reading of Bills

INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS

A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting the department of social services from requiring an applicant for a rental assistance voucher to have resided or reside in a shelter of any type, and to repeal sections 21-145.1 and 21-145.2 of such code in relation thereto
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting the department of social services from requiring an applicant for a rental assistance voucher to have resided or reside in a shelter of any type.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to exit surveys and interviews for resigning and retiring employees of city agencies
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Service and Labor
Items.MatterName: Exit surveys and interviews for resigning and retiring employees of city agencies.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the United States Congress to pass, and the President to sign, H.R.9319, known as the SNAP Theft Protection Act of 2022.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare
Items.MatterName: SNAP Theft Protection Act of 2022 (H.R.9319)

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, A.7001B/S.6677A to enact the Gender Identity Respect, Dignity and Safety Act, which would allow for appropriate treatment and placement of incarcerated people based upon their gender identity.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Criminal Justice
Items.MatterName: Gender Identity Respect, Dignity and Safety Act (A.7001B/S.6677A)

Items.Title: Resolution approving the new designation and changes in the designation of certain organizations to receive funding in the Expense Budget.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Approving the new designation and changes in the designation of certain organizations to receive funding in the Expense Budget.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the installation of bollards at reconstructed sidewalks, curb extensions and pedestrian ramps
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure
Items.MatterName: Installation of bollards at reconstructed sidewalks, curb extensions and pedestrian ramps.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring that 311 allow persons to request snow and ice removal on pedestrian bridges and that those reports be routed to the appropriate agency
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Technology
Items.MatterName: Requiring that 311 allow persons to request snow and ice removal on pedestrian bridges and that those reports be routed to the appropriate agency.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the 311 customer service center to provide live chat functionality
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Technology
Items.MatterName: Requiring the 311 customer service center to provide live chat functionality.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature and Governor to fully fund the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) in the State’s upcoming Fiscal Year 2024 Budget in an effort to ensure that: public transit riders have effective, affordable public transportation; the MTA maintains fiscal stability in the face of a looming fiscal cliff; and the MTA operate more frequent bus and train service statewide.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure
Items.MatterName: NYS Legislature and Governor to fully fund the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) in the State’s upcoming Fiscal Year 2024 Budget.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, A.568/S.1802 prohibiting municipalities from requiring all employers to check prospective employees’ work authorization status by using the federal electronic verification system and prohibiting employers from checking the employment authorization status of an existing employee or an applicant who has not been offered employment.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Immigration
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting municipalities from requiring all employers to check prospective employees’ work authorization status by using the federal electronic verification system. (A.568/S.1802)

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the operation of motorized scooters, and to repeal subdivision e of section 19-176.2 of such code, relating to operators of electric scooters and bicycles with electric assist
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure
Items.MatterName: Operation of motorized scooters, and to repeal subdivision e of section 19-176.2 of such code, relating to operators of electric scooters and bicycles with electric assist.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring that balloons made with electrically conductive material and filled with gas lighter than air be weighted and include warning labels
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer and Worker Protection
Items.MatterName: Requiring that balloons made with electrically conductive material and filled with gas lighter than air be weighted and include warning labels.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to allow seniors and people with disabilities to receive fare discounts on express buses during rush hours, between the hours of 6 am to 10 am and between 3 pm and 7 pm on Monday through Friday.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure
Items.MatterName: MTA to allow seniors and people with disabilities to receive fare discounts on express buses during rush hours, between the hours of 6 am to 10 am and between 3 pm and 7 pm on Monday through Friday..

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, legislation allowing family and friends of incarcerated individuals to deliver packages in person during prison visits.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Criminal Justice
Items.MatterName: Allowing family and friends of incarcerated individuals to deliver packages in person during prison visits.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the U.S. Congress to repeal the Merchant Marine Act of 1920, commonly known as the “Jones Act”.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 7 Council Members formally noted their intention to vote negative on this item:  
Council Members Ariola, Carr, Holden, Kagan, Paladino, Vernikov, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Borelli).

The following Council Member formally noted his intention to abstain from voting on this item:  
Council Member Yeger.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: U.S. Congress to repeal the Merchant Marine Act of 1920, commonly known as the “Jones Act”.

Items.Title: Resolution supporting a democratically governed public entity that will provide reliable and affordable electrical power to the people of Puerto Rico and supporting the immediate cancellation of the contract with LUMA Energy.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 7 Council Members formally noted their intention to vote negative on this item:  
Council Members Ariola, Carr, Holden, Kagan, Paladino, Vernikov, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Borelli).

The following Council Member formally noted his intention to abstain from voting on this item:  
Council Member Yeger.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Supporting a democratically governed public entity that will provide reliable and affordable electrical power to the people of Puerto Rico and supporting the immediate cancellation of the contract with LUMA Energy.

Items.MinutesNote: The Majority Leader (Council Member Powers) presiding as the President Pro Tempore.

The presence of a quorum was announced by the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers).

There were 50 Council Members marked present at this Stated Meeting.

The Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such motion which was decided in the affirmative by the following vote:
At this point the Speaker (Council Member Adams) made the following announcements:

Whereupon on motion of the Speaker (Council Member Adams), the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) adjourned these proceedings to meet again for the Stated Meeting of Thursday, February 2, 2023.

MICHAEL McSWEENEY, City Clerk
Clerk of the Council

Items.Title: Application number C 200012 ZSM (213-227 West 28th Street Parking Special Permits) submitted by 215 West 28th Street Property Owner LLC, pursuant to Sections 197-c and 201 of the New York City Charter for the grant of a special permit pursuant to Sections 13-45 (Special Permits for additional parking spaces) and 13-451 (Additional parking spaces for residential growth)  of the Zoning Resolution to allow an automated accessory parking garage with a maximum capacity of 41 spaces on portions of the ground floor, cellar and sub-cellar levels 1, 2 and 3, of a proposed mixed-use building at 213-219 West 28th Street (Block 778, Lot 31), on a zoning lot located at 213-227 West 28th Street (Block 778, Lots 25 & 31), in an M1-6D District.
